Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2014 08:02AM Garlikbread wrote: fluff/Jill, im sorry you gals are experiencing this. for almost a month I was very nausea and throwing up every single thing all day. I would literally wake up and within 5 minutes I was running for the toilet. I was very miserable. I'm not sure if you all have tried it but what worked for me was steroids that my mo prescribed. ¬†Zofran did not help me at all and another med my mo prescribed made me feel like I was "high" and very paranoid. ¬†I hope that you both find something that will help with the nausea
Posts.Title: is this the best it's going to be from now on? Fluffernutter Zillsnot4me

Posts.Content: Jun 2, 2015 08:19PM Garlikbread wrote: ladies thank you for the kind words. I haven't been on in a lil while. Although I'm on anti depressants i still struggle everyday trying not to be sad when I look at my boys. It breaks my heart
Posts.Title: Depressed Mom Garlikbread LindaE54

Posts.Content: Garlikbread wrote: hey ladies, I am too embarrassed to talk to my family or friends but I'm finding that more and more everyday I am getting very sad. I've never had a history of depression until about 7 months after I was diagnosed, and has gotten worse since progression last Nov, my SIL passing from cancer in Dec and more progression inJan of this year. I have two sons and a husband and every time I see a mom with their kids I cry, every time I look at my boys who are young I get sad and visualize a time clock over my head that's counting down. I have major anxiety too for which I take Xanax but that causes me to have scary dreams. I'm just tired that this is my life now. I hate that I have to put on a smile and play tough for everyone and still try to be a wife and a mom. I'm just so tired. Posts.Content: Nov 30, 2013 05:10AM Garlikbread wrote: From my new experience with all this (I'm only a week in) the techs do the mammo/us and the radiologists reads it. In my case the radiologist came into the room and did the ultrasound herself as well before she started to really talk to me. I'm in ga as well and many of the places tell you if they want a biopsy or if you're ok. They read results before you leave office. The dr can answer many questions. I don't think the techs are supposed to answer any detail questions as far as reading images. Sending happy news your way

Her fear is that one of the tumors will break through because of the size?? I didn't even know that was possible. My thoughts now are that I will trade one problem for another (lymph edema).

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2014 12:16AM Garlikbread wrote: Tina I agree with all the ladies. What a coincidence that I finally shared with my hubby at dinner earlier¬†that I have been sad more now than before and I was going to ask my mo for some meds to help control it. So if it makes you feel better we all go to the place we shouldn't but we are human. I also have a 10 year old that did not want me to wear my bald head out so anytime I went out and we were together I wore that hot azz wig and many days I felt like taking it off before getting home. As far as the guilt goes I think thats just being a mom. We want to take care of our family but feel bad when they have to take care of us. I still struggle with the fact that I'm not the same person I was 6 months ago and my boys for literally the first time in their lives see me sick. Many times i fake how i feel so that they dont see me hurting. If u can't get your emotions under control I would ask for some meds to help. Feeling sad is normal for many stage IVers.¬†
Posts.Title: Feeling sad Tina72 starbrightlyshines

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2014 08:13AM Garlikbread wrote: Angie I am in some level of pain everyday with bone mets. I did have radiation and that helped a lot. I wish I could have a pain free day! I don't do oxy anymore because it makes me sleepy. Ibuprofen has worked better for me
Posts.Title: Pain all the time? angiephnx springwatch

Posts.Content: Aug 30, 2014 02:44AM Garlikbread wrote: Chris I'm sorry you're having problems with your port. I remember when u got your new port. When I got my port in jan I told them that I was allergic to glue but when i woke up they put surgical glue on the incisions. When I went for my 1st chemo infusion the tech said that my port was not healing and they had to sit and remove all the glue which in turn opened the incisions back up. So now my port area has a very visible scar where it opened back up. I hope they figure your port out and I pray that it's not infected Margie
Posts.Title: old port problems again chris1959 Garlikbread

Posts.Content: May 5, 2014 07:46PM Garlikbread wrote: I remember that with ssdi the kids get a percentage of your overall monthly allowance. If you pass away their percentage increases. This is how it was explained to me. Maybe when your son turns 18 your monthly amount may increase? Probably not I'm sure. Can't wait to see what the answer is¬†
Posts.Title: SSDI Question Romansma Romansma

Posts.Content: May 7, 2014 07:56PM Garlikbread wrote: Kat You can have their money deposited into your account or you can have it deposited into their account. I have mines going into their accounts. We have a 15 and a 10 year old. Since they are minors you will be listed as the guardian over their benefits. In the event that something happens the kids new guardian would have to inform SS of their new guardian. I believe my case mgr said in that event the benefits will stop until a new guardian is added

The story reminds me of when we told my sons of the cancer diagnosis and that the doctors are going to make me better (I gave them hope when I myself did not have hope). It broke my heart when the wife had to tell her son that the doctors can't make her better and she will die . I don't ever want to tell my boys that there is nothing else for me. I don't want my boys to go through life not having their mom. I don't want them to experience the ¬†saddens of losing a parent¬†

Posts.Title: I did it. I finished a Half Marathon Garlikbread usafmom

Posts.Content: Garlikbread wrote: I completed the Run Like A Diva half marathon. I never would have thought today was possible. Chemo, fractured hip 3 months ago and rods in my hip and femur, the on and off sickness from day to day. I hadn't run since the diagnosis in Dec because I was extremely sick. I had no training for this race but in my heart I wanted to do it and I prayed for endurance. In my head I said at least I will try and worse case scenario I don't finish. Well this Stage IV girl did it today!! I'm so proud of myself and thankful that God have me the strength I needed to do it. I love my medal and will be wearing it for a couple days and especially to my monthly dr appt because my radiologist was against my running and my surgeon didn't think it was a good idea Margie¬† Learning to really live outside my comfort level Dx 12/2/2013, IDC, 6cm+, Stage IV, Grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER2- Radiation Therapy 12/22/2013 Bone Chemotherapy 1/14/2014 AC Chemotherapy 3/15/2014 Taxol (paclitaxel) Hormonal Therapy 3/30/2014 Hormonal Therapy 11/25/2014 Femara (letrozole) Chemotherapy 2/17/2015 Xeloda (capecitabine) Dx IDC, Stage IIIB, Grade 2, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2015 10:43AM Garlikbread wrote: Hi Ladies, I will post here and start a new thread because I need all the help I can get. I was diagnosed bone mets 12/2013 and in nov/2014 I had my first progression to liver and dr took me off tamoxifen and put me on Femara and a shot to shut down ovaries. I had liver ablation 12/2014. I had my scans this past Wednesday and today my Onc told me there is more progression in liver, 3 new spots showed up and she is suggesting we ditch hormonals and go back on chemo and start xeloda. As u can imagine my balloon of hope has deflated again. Is this the end for me? How many have been here and xeloda worked and got them to stable? The IR is suggesting a Y90 procedure?? I told my hubs first and then I told him that I'm turning to my peers on bco. Margie
Posts.Title: How are people with liver mets doing? blondie1 JFL

They are giving me a shot to shut ovaries down because I'm only 38 and a hormonal Femara Margie

Posts.Content: Jun 30, 2014 12:06AM Garlikbread wrote: I had red devil as my first line of treatment as I was diagnosed stage IV right out the gate. They hand pushed the adriamyacin to my IV it did not hand from pole. I got 2 big fat syringes of it every 2 weeks. For me personally it kicked my butt. Had to have a couple blood transfusions. ¬†I don't think it got better with each infusion I just learned how to deal with the side effects and I knew by day 7 I should start to feel better. Nevertheless it's doable u just have to accept that for some it may be hard and for others the se are not that bad. Only thing I liked about it was that my time from start to finish on chemo days was about 3 hours. I got adriamyacin and cytoxin (sp).¬†

Posts.Content: Jun 23, 2015 02:56PM Garlikbread wrote: Chris I had a rod placed in my hip and in my femur to support the hip last Year. A couple days after coming home from hospital I fell down the stairs only because I was being stubborn and didn't want help. The recovery from surgery wasn't too bad but it did take me several months to get rid of very noticeable limp although I still have a slight one. If it's any consolation I did run a half marathon 4 months after surgery. I also had to do the shots for about 21 days daily and the only side effect I had was my stomach had all these pin size red lil bumps all over. They didn't itch or hurt. I looked it and that was a side effect. I wish u a fast recovery
